jink

easier, jadier Ink

Jink is an abstraction on Ink authored in Jade , you must go through Ink's documentation to understand the modules. Jink is a one-on-one mapping to Ink, written in Jade. Understanding Ink and writing markup with jade is a pre-requisite for using Jink.

Jink also attempts to be a workflow for hand-crafting email templates. Right now, it includes a grunt task which inlines the associated styles using Premailer but we look forward to add more tasks which takes off the load.

Introduction

As email templates are built using nested table structures, even simpler Ink modules adds up to a nested tags disaster.

And on top of that, with Ink you have to remember the elements on which you have to apply the helper classes

Jink abstracts the html structure provided by Ink and expresses everything in terms of Ink's modules like container, row, columns, sub-columns, block-grid, and buttons.

Here is Ink's basic manifesto.

Structure

Ink uses a 12-column grid with a 580px wrapper. On mobile devices (under 580px wide), columns become full width and stack vertically.

Ink's grid can be thought of in terms of three components:

Containers

Ink containers wrap the content and maintain a fixed, 580px layout on large displays. Below 580px, containers take up 95% of the screen's width, ensuring that your content doesn't run right up against the edges of the user's screen.

Rows

Rows are used to separate blocks of content vertically. In addition to the vertical separation, the

tags of .row tables use the wrapper class to maintain a gutter between columns. Note: the last .wrapper in a row MUST have a class of .last applied to it, even if it's the only wrapper in the row (ex. for a row with a single, twelve-column wide content area).

Columns

Columns denote the width of the content, as based on a 12-column system. The content inside them will expand to cover n-columns, assuming that the number of columns in one row adds up to 12.

Lets look at a basic example.

Eight Columns
Four Columns 
+container()
  +row()
    +columns('eight')
      td Eight Columns
    +columns('four', 'last')
      td Four Columns

Jink uses jade mixins to reuse the HTML structures that makes up an Ink module.

This effort attempts to minimize authoring of markup that doesn't describe your content.

The above jink markup expands to the markup below. Jink already takes care of applying the proper helper classes to any <td> or <table> if required and maintaining the HTML structure.

  <table class="container">
    <tr>
      <td>
        <table class="row">
          <tr>
            <td class="wrapper">
              <table class="eight columns">
                <tr>
                  <td>
                    Eight Columns
                  </td>
                  <td class="expander"></td>
                </tr>
              </table>
            </td>
            <td class="wrapper last">

              <table class="four columns">
                <tr>
                  <td>
                    Four Columns
                  </td>
                  <td class="expander"></td>
                </tr>
              </table>
            </td>
          </tr>
        </table>
      </td>
    </tr>
  </table>

Reference

Every module in Jink is a jade mixin. You insert(indent) the desired content inside the mixin.

+container( )

Similar to Ink's container module. Indents all the rows under it. If you want to add a custom class to it, pass it as an attribute to the jade mixin.

+container()(class="newsletter")

compiles to 

<table class="container">
  <tr>
    <td>
      [Content Goes Here]
    </td>
  </tr>
</table>

+row( )

Same as Ink's row. Indents all the columns under it. If you want to add a custom class to it, pass it as an attribute to the jade mixin.

+row()(class="happy-news")

compiles to 

<table class="row">
  <tr>
    [Content Goes Here]
  </tr>
</table>

+columns( )

Same as Ink's columns. Indent the content under it.

Content in a column should be enclosed within a <td> element.

Column is the most elementary unit in the grid system. You can have multiple columns inside a row.

To indicate the number of grids a column covers, you have to apply a class on the enclosing <table> element which represents a column.

But with Jink, you pass in the class name as the first parameter to the column mixin.

The class can be any number from one to twelve expressed in words.

+columns('twelve')
  td
    h1 We are celebrating just like that
    p 
      | So, you everything you buy is 
      | free for a limited time
      | because celebration can't last forever.
      
      
            can use helper classes provided by Ink on td elemement inside a column.
            
+container()(class="happy-news")


            you want to add a custom class to it, pass it as an attribute to the 
            mixin.
+container()(class="happy-news")

compiles to 

<table class="row">
  <tr>
    [Content Goes Here]
  </tr>
</table>
